title: Titchfield Haven Walking Route

images.title: Pierre Terre / Titchfield Haven, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The view from the bridge.

images.title: Pierre Terre / The beach at Titchfield Haven, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The beach at Titchfield Haven. Looking east towards Hill Head.

images.title: Colin Babb / Titchfield Haven, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Boats at the haven

images.title: Martin Speck / Sea wall at Titchfield Haven, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The sea wall looking towards Meon Shore Chalets. The power station at Fawley can bee seen on the horizon, on the far bank of Southampton Water. The oil-fired power station is next to the oil refinery, also visible on the horizon as a forest of fractional distillation towers. Power is fed out by a tunnel under Southampton Water to a line of pylons, just visible behind Solent Breezes Holiday Village.

images.title: Colin Babb / Reed Beds at Titchfield Haven, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Reed beds. The reed beds have roosting platforms built in them

images.title: Colin Babb / Titchfield Canal-Titchfield, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Titchfield Canal. This little ditch was a canal which was dug to get boats to Titchfield from the sea at Titchfield Haven. It was one of the earliest canals in England, dating from the 1600s. I can only imagine that it was once bigger or that the boats using it were not much more than rowing boats. It parallels the River Meon and gets it's water from it. There was a sea lock near the haven. The remains of which can still be seen.

images.title: Pierre Terre / Viewing Area, Titchfield Haven, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: An area for informal bird watching

images.title: Barry Shimmon / Visitor centre for the Titchfield Haven Nature Reserve, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Visitor centre

description: Explore this beautiful coastal nature reserve and enjoy a stroll along the Titchfield Canal on this circular walk near Fareham. The reserve boasts 369 acres of River, fen, pools, reedbed and meadow. These habitats attract a wide range of water loving wildlife. Look out for Reed Warblers, Bearded Tits, Water rails and Bittern around the reedbeds and Otters by the River Meon. There are a number of hides from which you can observe the wildlife. Other facilities include the Titchfield Haven Visitor Centre, tea room and exhibition about the history of the Solent area. This walk starts at the car park near Hillhead Harbour and takes you along the coast passing the Meon Shore chalets. You then turn inland and pass Bromwich Pond and some nice countryside before coming to the village of Titchfield. Here you could head north of the village and visit the interesting 13th century Titchfield Abbey. There are attractive grounds with ponds and major remains of the abbey to see. From Titchfield a waterside section along the Titchfield Canal and the River Meon takes you back to the car park. The Solent Way passes the reserve so you could pick this up to continue your walk. If you head south east you will come to Lee on Solent and Gosport. If you head west you will come to Southampton.
